items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
This is an opportunity for members of the public to address the Board concerning issues not listed on the agenda.
	 
The Board welcomes this opportunity to hear from the public and has established a policy for the public's participation in board meetings, which is outlined in BP 2345. This policy states that:
	 
No member of the public may speak without being recognized by the President of the Board.
Each speaker will be allowed a maximum of three minutes per topic. Thirty minutes shall be the maximum time allotment for public speakers on any one subject regardless of the number of speakers at any one Board meeting. At the discretion of a majority of the Board, these time limits may be extended.
The Board recognizes the need to encourage public participation but also recognizes the need to preserve order and the proper functioning of the meeting. Citizens addressing the Board at meetings shall therefore conduct themselves at all times in a manner appropriate to the setting.

1. Evergreen Valley College Adjunct Faculty
Per the collective bargaining agreement between the AFT 6157 and San Jose/Evergreen Community College District Article 9.13 submission and recommendation:
Article 9.13 ASSIGNMENT LENGTH AND MAXIMUM LOADING - Adjunct faculty members shall be responsible and accountable for all District assigned service during the college semester for which they are employed. Assignments are limited to a maximum of 67% of a full load.
Therefore, the attached information is in compliance with Article 9.13 of the Faculty Association AFT 6157 Collective Bargaining Agreement with San Jose/Evergreen Community College District.

items.item_details: The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.

items.item_details:
Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the District until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees. Board Policy 6100 established the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval. All contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions exceeding the current bid limit of $87,800 shall have prior Board approval as a separate board item.
This consent item presents for Board approval: all purchase orders for this period, which includes purchase orders for administratively approved contracts exceeding $1,000, as well as additional contracts, although not executed by way of purchase order, are deemed appropriate to be added by the Purchasing Department.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees ratify the contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions for the period of February 10, 2016 through March 9, 2016 as noted in the attached documents.

items.item_details:
San Jose City College will participate in the East Side Alliance Career Pathways Initiative in cooperation with other consortium partners to design and implement a dual/concurrent enrollment program for East Side students.
	 
General Agreements
San Jose City College will:
 Collaborate with the East Side Union High School District to adapt and develop rigorous curriculum, participate in training and staff development, and conduct joint outreach and marketing to inform and recruit low income, underrepresented, and special population students into high skill, high wage careers in targeted industry sectors.
Collaborate jointly with East Side and industry and community partners to align rigorous college coursework with relevant technical skills and workplace competencies, as defined by industry, and provide support for students to complete the pathway and transition to employment.
Provide guidance in the development of a dual credit/concurrent enrollment program in identified pathway sectors in the Career Pathways Trust application.
	 
Specific Requirements
San Jose City College will:
Provide dedicated faculty liaison(s) to focus on design, development, and planning of dual credit/concurrent enrollment program and curriculum alignment.
Provide faculty/staff to participate in cohort and team building activities attend collaboration meetings and staff training for identified industry sectors.
Participate in reporting and evaluation required by the East Side Alliance Consortium and the California Department of Education.
Provide in-kind or other match of $49,750 to support above activities.
	 
	 
Budgeted Amount
Faculty liaisons for dual credit/concurrent enrollment program design and planning, curriculum alignment, participation in cohort and team building activities, collaboration meetings, staff training and professional development
$100,000
Outreach Transition Specialist
65,000
Benefits for Transition Specialist
15,750
Benefits for faculty liaisons
35,000
Total
$215,750.00
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees accept $215,750 in grant funds from the Chancellor's Office in partnership with East Side Alliance Career Pathways Initiative for the design and implementation of a dual/concurrent enrollment program for East Side Union High School District.
items.item_text: Acceptance of Grant Funds for San Jose City College's participation in the East Side Alliance Career Pathways Initiative

items.item_details:
This is a student-led initiative to name the veterans center and call our veterans-serving program and area the Veterans Freedom Center.  Veteran students from the Veterans Students Club met several times regarding this issue and created five different options of names for the center.  The Veterans Student Club President went to the Associated Student Government and presented several name options.  The Associated Student Government voted to support the name choices of the Veterans Student Club.
	 
On March 14, 2016 the Veterans Student Club presented under “Information Items” to the College Council two different possible names.  The College Council recommended choosing one name and returning at the next meeting to vote on the name.  The Veterans Student Club went to College Council on March 28, 2016 and presented one option – the Veterans Freedom Center – to the College Council for “Action” and the College Council approved the name.  
	 
The President of Evergreen Valley College has also approved the name – Veterans Freedom Center.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the name of the Evergreen Valley College veterans center as Veterans Freedom Center.

items.item_details:
San Jose/Evergreen Community College District (hereinafter "District") wishes to establish an agreement to partner with Campbell Union School District (hereinafter "Contractor").  The District will enter into a certain agreement entitled Child Development Services California State Preschool Program (CSPP), dated March 21, 2016 (Contract Number: CSPP #5531; hereinafter "Local Agreement") with the California Department of Education (hereinafter CDE).  
	 
The Contractor shall provide child development services in accordance with this Agreement, the Local Agreement, and such other documents as either may incorporate by reference, and all applicable law, based on minimum school year of 246 days of operations and 6,178 child days of enrollment not including the allowable factors permitted by CDE and parent fees earnings.
	 
As the certified CDC contractor, San Jose City College will continue to conduct fiscal agent responsibilities and compliance checks to meet the conditions of its contract with the California Department of Education, Child Development Division and to adhere to the Funding and Conditions (FT&C).
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation to the Board of Trustees to approve the Subcontractor Agreement between San Jose/Evergreen Community College District and Campbell Union School District.

items.item_details:
Per California Public Contract Code Section 20652, "The governing board of any community college district without advertising for bids, and when the board as determined it to be in the best interest of the district, may authorize by contract, lease, requisition or purchase order... (to) purchase materials, supplies , equipment... and other personal property for the district in the manner in which the public corporation or agency is authorized by law to make the lease or purchase." The contract must be based on the same prices and upon the same terms and conditions of the negotiated contract between the supplier and another public corporation or agency.
	 
Therefore, when considering the best interest for the District , it is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize the use of a "piggyback" contract between National Auto Fleet Group and National Joint Powers Alliance for the purchase of six vehicles; four Ford F-250 trucks and two Ford Transit Connect Vans without the need to further advertise for bids on an already competitively bid contract. The award of this contract will allow greater flexibility for the San Jose Evergreen Community College District staff in providing vehicles, installed options, and accessories. 
	 
Attached is proof of publication (bid advertisement), NJPA approval and award and renewal of agreements, and quote from National Auto Fleet Group to San Jose Evergreen Community College District under the National Joint Powers Alliance Bid Number 102811.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees authorize the District to utilize an existing contract between National Auto Fleet Group and National Joint Powers Alliance to "piggyback" purchase six vehicles (four Ford F-250 trucks and two Ford Transit Connect Vans) and approve the purchase of vehicles listed under Measure G 2010 Vehicle Replacement Group 2.
items.item_text: Measure G- 2010 Bond Program: Replacement of aging and non-functioning vehicles
items.item_text_raw: 2. Measure G- 2010 Bond Program: Replacement of aging and non-functioning vehicles

items.item_details:
This project will provide network infrastructure improvements campus-wide including; 1) fiber optics cabling to the new main distribution facility, all building distribution facilities, and electrical upgrades to support the new network equipment upgrade, 2) network cabling and installation of wireless access points, 3) and network cabling across campus to support a new integrated security system.
	 
Specifically, this project provides security upgrades that include; 1) public safety video system, 2) emergency communication system; emergency phones and mass notification system, 3) access upgrades to the building intrusion alarm system, and 4) integration and monitoring of the security systems at the police command center.  The project’s goal:  provide robust, scalable, wired and wireless infrastructure to support high volume network access by all constituents for learning, instruction, operations, research, communications, facilities, and security with future growth throughout the campus in support of the college mission.
	 
The project was posted on the District’s purchasing website and advertised in local papers on February 25, 2016 and March 3, 2016.  It was published at local builders’ exchanges and plan rooms.  In addition, invitations to bid were sent to many contractors including small minority and woman-owned firms.  On March 17, 2016 construction bids were received as follows:
	 
Company Name               Base Bid             Alternate Total       Total Contract Value                          
Cupertino Electric, Inc.     $3,791,840         $45,240                 $3,837,080                             
           
Cupertino Electric, Inc. from San Jose, California was the sole responsive and responsible bidder with a base bid in the amount of $3,791,840.
	 
The District received good contractor participation in the bidding process with twelve (12) contractors attended our mandatory bid walk.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the award of an Agreement in the amount of $3,837,080 to Cupertino Electric Inc., for the IT Infrastructure Improvements EVC-2016 Network Upgrades Project #32702 at Evergreen Valley College.
items.item_text: Measure G – 2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College IT Infrastructure Improvements EVC-2016 Network Upgrades Project #32702 – Cupertino Electric, Inc. Agreement
items.item_text_raw: 3. Measure G – 2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College IT Infrastructure Improvements EVC-2016 Network Upgrades Project #32702 – Cupertino Electric, Inc. Agreement

items.item_details:
The contract for the Main Data Frame Relocation #39310 at Evergreen Valley College was necessary to create the necessary Information Technology infrastructure on the Evergreen Valley College Campus.
	 
On August 25, 2015, the Board of Trustees approved an Agreement to Rodan Builders, Inc. in the amount of $960,000 to provide construction services for the Main Data Frame Relocation Project #39310 at Evergreen Valley College. On September 3, 2015 construction activity began and on January 28, 2016, major construction activity was completed.  As of February 11, 2016, all construction work has been approved by the Architect of Record, all closeout documents have been received and the final Change Order has been presented and approved on March 8, 2016.
	 
Once approved, this Notice of Completion (NOC) will be filed with the County of Santa Clara, Office of the Recorder.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Notice of Completion (NOC) of the contract by Rodan Builders, Inc. Main Data Frame Relocation Project #39310 at Evergreen Valley College.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College Main Data Frame Relocation Project #39310 – Rodan Builders, Inc. Notice of Completion (NOC)
items.item_text_raw: 4. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College Main Data Frame Relocation Project #39310 – Rodan Builders, Inc. Notice of Completion (NOC)

items.item_details:
On August 26, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved an Agreement to Blach Construction Company in the amount of $41,639,729 to provide construction services for the South Campus Development Project #32107 at Evergreen Valley College.
Deductive Change Order No. 015 includes Work that is the result of costs and credits from:  revision of the landscape layout, planting and irrigation at Stair A, deletion of the roof tie backs near the skylight, addition of cain rails at Stair B, reconciliation of Bid Package No. 12, addition of a connecting site path and the revision of card reader locations and door hardware orientation.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                                             $41,639,729.00
Previous Approved Changes                                        $     445,654.00
Deductive Change Order No. 015                                $      (13,725.00)
Total Contract and Changes                                         $42,071,658.00
	 
The net change to Blach Construction Company’s contract as a result of all changes issued is $431,929.00 which equates to 1.03% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change.
	 
The Project Completion Date remains unchanged at March 10, 2016.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Deductive Change Order No. 015 in the amount of ($13,725.00) to Blach Construction Company for the South Campus Development Project #32107 at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_text_raw: 5. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Evergreen Valley College South Campus Development Project #32107 – Blach Construction Company Deductive Change Order No. 015

items.item_details:
On May 30, 2014 the Board of Trustees agreed to enter into contract with Signet Testing Laboratories, Inc. for special testing and inspection services for the South Campus Development Project #32107 at Evergreen Valley College. 
	 
Independent Contractor Agreement (ICA) Revision No. 002 includes additional testing for the welding of the handrails and testing of the ceiling wiring grid system.  Signet Testing Laboratories, Inc. was requested to provide additional services outside the Terms of their ICA in order to maintain construction progress.  Signet Testing Laboratories, Inc. submitted a written proposal for changes that include additional work.  The proposal has been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
           
Original Contract Amount             $140,000.00
Previous Approved Revisions      $  82,160.00
This Revision No. 002                  $    6,697.23
Total Contract and Changes         $228,857.23
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve an Independent Contractor Agreement (ICA) Revision No. 002 in the amount of $6,697.23 to Signet Testing Laboratories, Inc. for additional special testing and inspection services for the South Campus Development Project #32107 at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
On May 26, 2015, the Board of Trustees approved an Agreement to Taber Construction, Inc. in the amount of $7,115,000 to provide construction services for the Central Green / Arts Plaza Project #32116 at Evergreen Valley College.
	 
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions or District requested design changes that require an adjustment to the contract scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Final Change Order No. 003 includes a credit of un-used allowance funding which was not used during the project, repair pre-existing damage to gutters, drainage inlets and concrete seat walls adjacent to the project site to correct safety and storm water drainage issues, cost over the “Not to Exceed” cost included in Change Order No. 001 to transport recycled water from an off-site hydrant to the Central Green / Arts Plaza, repair existing in-ground lighting in Arts Plaza which was non-functional prior to the start of the project, adjust elevation for existing water valve boxes along Gullo Firelane which were not shown on contract documents, provide and install landscaping adjacent to newly installed Arts Plaza work for visual consistency and added safety, provide and install roof drain scupper at Student Services building to prevent water from entering building basement, provide planning, coordination and field labor to assist with Campus-Wide recycled water cross-connection testing to comply with City of San Jose regulations, replacement of a fire hydrant which failed as a result of the campus wide cross connection testing, and a non-compensable weather related schedule extension of forty (40) calendar days extending the project substantial completion date from January 1, 2016 to February 9, 2016 with a final completion date of March 4, 2016.
	 
Taber Construction Inc. submitted written pricing proposals for these changes (details in the Agenda attachment) that include the applicable increase or decrease in materials, equipment, labor, time extensions and overhead and profit.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                      $7,115,000.00
Previous Approved Changes                 $   416,343.00
Final Change Order No. 003                  $     56,218.00
Total Contract and Changes                   $7,587,561.00
	 
The net change to Taber Construction, Inc.’s contract as a result of all changes issued is $472,561 which equates to 6.64% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change. 
	 
The Substantial Completion Date is being revised to February 9, 2016, and is included with this Final Change Order.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Final Change Order No. 003 in the amount of $56,218 to Taber Construction, Inc. for the Central Green / Arts Plaza Project #32116 at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
The contract for the Central Green / Arts Plaza #32116 at Evergreen Valley College was necessary to construct new site improvements for the Evergreen Valley College Campus. 
	 
On May 27, 2015, the Board approved the contract for Taber Construction, Inc. to perform the Work.  On June 1, 2015 construction activity began and on February 9, 2016, major construction activity was completed.  As of March 4, 2016, all construction work has been approved by the Architect of Record, all closeout documents have been received and the final Change Order is being presented for approval on April 12, 2016 to close out the contract.   
	 
	 
The Board is asked to approve the Notice of Completion for the Central Green /Arts Plaza Project.
	 
Once approved, this NOC will be filed with the County of Santa Clara, Office of the Recorder.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Notice of Completion (NOC) of the contract by Taber Construction, Inc. for the Central Green / Arts Plaza Project #32116 at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
On February 10, 2015 the Board agreed to enter into a contract with Bellinger Foster Steinmetz (BFS) Landscape Architects to provide conceptual and schematic design, design development, construction documentation, estimating and construction administration including Division of the State Architect (DSA) review and closeout, for the Campus Site Improvements South Campus Connection at Evergreen Valley College (EVC). 
	 
Project Assignment Amendment No. EVC-03 Revision No. 001 includes the following:  1) Addition of the EVC Signage and Wayfinding project design, DSA review and approval, bidding assistance, construction administration and closeout, 2) Signage sub-consultant costs and contract, and 3) Extends the contract end date from 6/30/2016 to 6/30/2017.  The District solicited pricing proposals from qualified signage designers to update the EVC Campus Signage Master Plan, provide signage and wayfinding construction documents, and provide construction administration and closeout services.  The signage consultant will be a subconsultant to BFS' contract in order to include this scope of work in the existing site improvements project.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.  The recommended signage sub-consultant will be Ross Luthin Creative, which represents the best value to the District, is a Small Business Certified firm, and has significant experience with Campus Signage programs. 
	 
The following signage consultant pricing was received:
	 
1)   Ross Luthin Creative (SBE Certified) -      $78,000
2)   Propp + Guerin (SBE Certified) -               $85,000
3)   Square Peg - (Not SBE Certified) -            $86,800
	 
The item in this amendment results in an addition to the contract of $100,000.  
	 
Original Contract Amount                  $65,000
Previous Approved Revisions           $0
This Revision No. 001                       $100,000
Total Contract and Changes              $165,000
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Revision No. 001 to Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) EVC-03 in the amount of $100,000 to Bellinger Foster Steinmetz (BFS) Landscape Architects for Project #32113 Campus Site Improvements at Evergreen Valley College (EVC).

items.item_details:
A pre-construction services agreement with Lease Lease-Back (LLB) contractor Sundt Construction was approved by the Board of Trustees on February 11, 2014.  Prior to Sundt’s final preparation of their Guaranteed Maximum Price proposal, the Davis vs. Fresno court case regarding Fresno Unified School District's use of the LLB project delivery method caused SJECCD to re-evaluate the delivery method for this project. Ultimately, the decision was made to change to a Design-Bid-Build (DBB) delivery in combination with a pre-qualification process for prime contractors.
	 
A Request for Qualifications (RFQ) for DBB Contractors was issued November 17, 2015 with six (6) Statement of Qualifications (SOQ’s) returned on December 10, 2015. All six were selected to provide a Request for Proposal (RFP).
	 
The RFP was issued on January 20, 2016 with three (3) prime contractors submitting a proposal. RFP’s were due on March 10, 2016 and were received as follows:
	 
            Alten Constructon, Inc.                                           $17,518,000
            SJ Amoroso Construction Co., Inc.                        $17,997,000
            T.B. Penick & Sons, Inc.                                         $18,665,493
	 
Alten Construction, Inc.  from Richmond, CA  was determined to be the lowest responsive and responsible bidder with a base-bid amount of $16,513,000 and a bid-alternate price of $1,005,000 totaling $17,518,000. It is recommended that Alten Construction, Inc be awarded the contract for both the base-bid and alternate.
	 
As part of SJECCD’s commitment to the engagement of small and disadvantaged contractors/suppliers, attached for information, is Alten Construction's "Small & Disadvantaged Contractor/Supplier Utilization Form" submitted as part of their proposal, which indicates a proposed 26% M/W/DV/SBE Contract Amount of Base Bid.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the award of a contract in the amount of $17,518,000 to Alten Construction, Inc., for the Physical Education Building #122 at SJCC.

items.item_text_raw: 10. Measure G – 2004 Bond Program: San Jose City College(SJCC) - Physical Education Building #122 – Alten Construction, Inc. Construction Agreement

items.item_details:
The scope of this Agreement is to replace the existing Uninterrupted Power Supply (UPS) for the Main Distribution Facility (MDF) at San Jose City College. The existing UPS has exceeded it’s useful life and should be replaced to ensure reliability of network, phone services, and to protect existing equipment that support operations at San Jose City College. 
	 
The project was posted on the District’s purchasing website and advertised in local papers on February 18, 2016 and February 25, 2016. It was published at local builders’ exchanges and plan rooms.  In addition, invitations to bid were sent to many contractors including small minority and woman-owned firms.  On March 15, 2016 construction bids were received as follows:
	 
Company Name               Base Bid             Alternate Total       Total Contract Value    
TDN Electric, Inc.             $102,300             Not Submitted        $102,300                                
Radiant Electric, Inc.        $127,400             $5,500                    $132,900                                
Tennyson Electric, Inc.     $128,650             $28,900                  $157,550
	 
The bid package of the apparent low bidder, TDN, was incomplete, was not on the forms provided, and represented a bid based on scope different from the scope defined in the bid documents.  Legal counsel has advised that these are material irregularities that cannot be waived and that TDN Electric’s bid is non-responsive and should be rejected.
	 
Consequently, the second lowest bidder, Radiant Electric, Inc. from San Jose, California, is the lowest responsive and responsible bidder with a base bid in the amount of $127,400.   The District chooses to include the Add Alternate for a total contract value of $132,900.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees reject the bid of TDN Electric, Inc as non-responsive and award an Agreement in the amount of $132,900 to Radiant Electric, Inc. for the IT Infrastructure Improvements: MDF-UPS Replacement Project #31702 at San Jose City College.
items.item_text: Measure G – 2010: San Jose City College IT Infrastructure Improvements: MDF-UPS Replacement #31702 – Radiant Electric, Inc. Agreement
items.item_text_raw: 11. Measure G – 2010: San Jose City College IT Infrastructure Improvements: MDF-UPS Replacement #31702 – Radiant Electric, Inc. Agreement

items.item_details:
On February 11, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved a Preconstruction Services Agreement to Sundt Construction, Inc.  in the amount of $87,000 to provide preconstruction services for the Physical Education Building Project #122 at the SJCC. 
	 
Prior to Sundt’s final preparation of their Guaranteed Maximum Price proposal, the Davis v Fresno court case regarding Fresno Unified School District's use of the LLB project delivery method caused SJECCD to re-evaluate the delivery method for this project. Ultimately, the decision was made to change to a Design-Bid-Build (DBB) delivery in combination with a pre-qualification process for prime contractors.
	 
During the formation of the Design-Assist team, the Design-Assist Subcontractors agreed to defer their preconstruction service fees and include within their construction phase subcontracts. As the result of the delivery method being changed from LLB to DBB the Design-Assist Subcontractors will not be issued a construction phase subcontract.  The Design Assist Subcontractors now require compensation for their pre-construction services.
	 
Sundt Construction, Inc.  submitted a written pricing proposal for these changes (details in the attachment) that include the applicable increase in preconstruction services. The proposal has been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
	 
Original Contract Amount                      $  87,000
Previously Approved Changes              $  40,205
Revision No. 004                                   $177,247
	 
Revised Contract Amount                     $304,452
	 
The net change to Sundt Construction, Inc. contract as a result of all changes issued is $217,452 to the original contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Revision No. 004 in the amount of $177,247 to Sundt Construction, Inc., for the Physical Education Building Project #122 at SJCC.

On March 11, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved a contract to Kitchell CEM Inc. in the amount of $4,914,192.00 to provide construction services for the Career Technical Education Buildings 100 and 200, Project # 31107-2 at SJCC. This project was to provide more modern facilities and classrooms as well as augmenting various lab spaces throughout buildings 100 and 200.
	 
On March 11, 2014, the board approved the Agreement for Kitchell to perform the work. On June 1, 2014 construction activity began and on March 3, 2016 major construction activity was completed. All construction work has been approved by the Architect of Record, all closeout documents have been received, and all Change Orders have been approved.
	 
Once approved, this Notice of Completion (NOC) will be filed with the County of Santa Clara, Office of the Recorder.

items.item_details:
The Division of the State Architect (DSA) requires materials Testing and Inspection (T&I) services during the construction of the New Gym Sitework & Auxiliary Buildings.  The Request For Qualifications (RFQ) was advertised in the Daily Journal on November 17, 2015 and November 24, 2015, and posted on the District’s Purchasing Bids website and at local builders' exchanges and plan rooms. In addition, invitations to bid were sent to over 70 T&I firms including small, minority and woman-owned firms.  
	 
On December 11, 2015 the District received 8  proposals in response to a public Request For Proposal (RFP) for T&I services on the New Gym Sitework & Auxiliary Buildings #31125 at SJCC. The proposals were evaluated by District Purchasing with assistance from Gilbane. Proposals were scored based on best value.  Based on this review, Smith Emery of San Francicso was selected as the best value. A final scope of services was established at a "Not to Exceed" contract value of $110,000.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve an ICA in the amount of $110,000 to Smith Emery of San Francisco, for New Gym Sitework & Auxiliary Buildings #31125 - Testing & Inspection Services at SJCC.

On August 8, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved a contract to McCarthy Building Companies, Inc.  in the amount of $7,500,000 to provide construction services for San Jose-Evergreen Community College Extension. 
	 
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions or District requested design changes that require an adjustment to the contract scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order No. 001 is to provide trenching, conduit, utility vaults and transformer pad for the PG&E primary and secondary electrical feed into the electrical panel. 
	 
McCarthy Building Companies, Inc.  submitted written pricing proposals for these changes that include the applicable increase in materials, equipment, labor, and overhead and profit.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                    $7,500,000
Previously Approved Changes            $       0,000
Change Order No. 001                        $   100,473
	 
Revised Contract Amount                    $7,600,473
	 
The net change to McCarthy Building Companies, Inc. contract as a result of all changes issued is $100,473 which equates to 1.3% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 001 in the amount of $100,473 to McCarthy Building Companies, Inc. for the San Jose-Evergreen Community College Extension .

items.item_details: On October 14, 2014 the Board approved an ICA with Dasher Technologies for the installation of a firewall system at SJCC (Bond Project #31702). This ICA for installation services was approved at the same time as the purchase of the firewall system was approved. The installation of the firewall system occurred last in the overall infrastructure upgrade project at SJCC, after the expiration of the ICA term of agreement. ICA Revision No. 001 is to extend the end date of the term of the agreement from 6/30/15 to 6/30/16 (see attachment). There is no additional cost for this revision.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Independent Contractor Agreement (ICA) Revision No. 001 to Dasher Technologies for changing the end date of the term of the agreement from 6/30/15 to 6/30/16.

items.item_details:
A draft resolution in support of Renters' Rights & Rent Stabilization in San Jose was presented at the March 29, 2016 Board Legislative Committee Open Session meeting.  Based on the impact high rent increases have had over the last 5 years on San Jose students, the Board Legislative Committee unanimously voted to recommend to the full Board a "support" position on this final, attached resolution.  
	 
It is recommended that the Board adopts the attached Resolution No. 041216-4 in support of Renters' Rights & Rent Stabilization in San Jose.

items.item_details:
An Election was held in the San Jose-Evergreen Community College District on November 2, 2010 for the issuance and sale of general obligation bonds of the District for various purposes in the maximum amount of $268,000,000 (the “2010 Measure G”).  The District has previously caused the issuance of three series of bonds pursuant under the 2010 Measure G.  The District now desires to issue the fourth series of bonds (the Series D Bonds) under the 2010 Measure G in an amount not‑to-exceed $58,000,000 (the “Bonds”).  The Bonds are being authorized for sale for the purpose of providing funds to finance projects approved pursuant to the 2010 Measure G and to pay the costs of issuing the Bonds.
	 
(a)        Bond Resolution.  This Resolution authorizes the issuance of Bonds, specifies the basic terms, parameters and form of the Bonds, and approves the form of Purchase Contract and form of Preliminary Official Statement described below.  In particular, Section 1 of the Resolution establishes the maximum aggregate initial principal amount of the Bonds to be issued ($58,000,000).  Section 4 of the Resolution states the maximum underwriter’s discount (0.4%) with respect to the Bonds, the maximum legal interest rate on the Bonds, and authorizes the Bonds to be sold at a negotiated sale to Piper Jaffray & Co., as the underwriter (the “Underwriter”).  The Resolution authorizes the issuance of current interest bonds only; capital appreciation bonds are not authorized. 
	 
(b)        Form of Purchase Contract.  The Resolution approves the form of the Purchase Contract.  Pursuant to the Purchase Contract, the Underwriter will agree to buy the Bonds from the District.  All the conditions of closing the transaction are set forth in this document, including the documentation to be provided at the closing by various parties.  Upon the pricing of the Bonds, the final execution copy of the Purchase Contract will be prepared following this form.
	 
(c)        Form of Preliminary Official Statement.  The Resolution approves the form of the Preliminary Official Statement.  The Preliminary Official Statement (the “POS”) is the offering document describing the Bonds which may be distributed to prospective purchasers of the Bonds.  The POS discloses information with respect to, among other things, (i) the proposed uses of proceeds of the Bonds, (ii) the terms of the Bonds (interest rate, redemption terms, etc.), (iii) the bond insurance policy for the Bonds, if any, (iv) the security for repayment of the Bonds (the ad valorem property tax levy), (v) information with respect to the District’s tax base (upon which such ad valorem property taxes may be levied), (vi) District financial and operating data, (vii) continuing disclosure with respect to the Bonds and the District, and (viii) absence of material litigation and other miscellaneous matters expected to be of interest to prospective purchasers of the Bonds.  Following the pricing of the Bonds, a final Official Statement for the Bonds will be prepared, substantially in the form of the POS.
	 
(d)        Form of the Continuing Disclosure Certificate.  The form of the Continuing Disclosure Certificate can be found in APPENDIX C to the POS.  Effective July 3, 1995, all underwriters of municipal bonds are obligated to procure from any public agency issuing debt a covenant that such public agency will annually file “material financial information and operating data” with respect to such public agency through the web-based Electronic Municipal Market Access (“EMMA”) system maintained by the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board (a federal agency that regulates “broker-dealers,” including investment bank firms that underwrite municipal obligations).  This requirement is expected to be satisfied by the filing of the District’s audited financial statements and other operating information about the District, in the same manner the District has filed such information in connection with prior bond issuances.  The purpose of the law is to provide investors in the Bonds with current information regarding the District.  Similar laws have governed the corporate debt market for many years.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT
	 
	 
There is no fiscal impact to the General Fund resulting from the issuance of the Bonds.

items.item_details:
The contract with the District's Independent Auditor, Crowe-Horwath LLP, expired with the completion of the annual audit for fiscal year ending June 30, 2015.
	 
In order to comply with California Education Code Section 84040, which mandates that the Board of Trustees provide for an annual audit of all funds, books, and accounts of the District in accordance with regulations established by the Board of Governors and that the audit shall be made by certified public accountants licensed by the California Board of Accountancy, the District solicited requests for proposals in December 2015 to engage prospective bidders for the next five fiscal years.
	 
The District received four proposals for consideration.  The proposals were received from Cossolias, Wilson, Dominguez, and Levitt (CWDL); Crowe-Horwath, LLP; Vavrinek, Trine, Day & Co., LLP (VTD); and Wilkinson, Hadley, King, & Co., LLP.  The Evaluation Committee comprised of the Audit Committee Chairperson, the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services, the Executive Director of Fiscal Services, the Controller, and a Purchasing Agent extended an invitation to CWDL, Crowe-Horwath, and VTD based upon the following criteria:  capacity to perform (25%), pricing (50%), small business (5%), and references (20%).
	 
The Evaluation Committee met with the three bidders in February 2016.  After receiving each presentation, the Evaluation Committee is recommending that the Board of Trustees approve and award the contract to CWDL, a small business, in an amount not to exceed $88,450 for FY2015-16; $90,256 for FY2016-17; $92,088 for FY2017-18; $93,948 for FY2018-19; and $95,835 for FY2019-20 being the lowest responsive bid received for the District's annual audit and financial report; the Foundation's annual audit and financial report, and tax return; the District's General Obligation Bond Program's annual performance audit and financial report; the District's Other Post Employment Benefit (OPEB) annual audit and financial report; and the agreed-upon procedures associated with the Chancellor and Board of Trustees discretionary expenses.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve and award the contract for independent audit services to CWDL, Certified Public Accountants, a small business, in an amount not to exceed $88,450 for FY2015-16; $90,256 for FY2016-17; $92,088 for FY2017-18; $93,948 for FY2018-19; and $95,835 for FY2019-20.

items.item_details:
Education Code Section 76361 and Title V Section 58520 states that the governing board of a community college district may require students in attendance at a campus of the district to pay a fee for purposes of partially or fully recovering transportation costs incurred by the district upon the favorable vote of a majority of the students at a campus of the district who voted at an election on the question of whether or not the governing board should require all students to pay a fee for transportation services.
	 
The Associated Student Government is requesting that the Board of Trustees call for an election providing students the opportunity to vote on the following question:
	 
"Should the San Jose-Evergreen Community College District Board of Trustees require that all students have access to an ECO PASS and be assessed a mandatory transportation fee of up to $4.50 per semester for students enrolled in less than 6 units and $9.00 per semester for students enrolled in 6 or more units for purposes of partially or fully recovering transportation costs incurred by the District for transportation services provided by the Valley Transportation Authority (VTA) pursuant to California Education Code 76361 and Title V Section 58520?"
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees call for an election providing students the opportunity to vote on the question of whether or not the Board of Trustees should require all students to pay a fee for transportation services.
items.item_text: Transportation Service Fee Election
items.item_text_raw: 9. Transportation Service Fee Election

items.item_details: At the March 8, 2016, Governing Board Meeting, the Board Policy Ad Hoc Committee Chair, Trustee Wendy Ho, reported on behalf of the other committee members, President Rudy Nasol and Trustee Mayra Cruz, that the committee met on March 3 to further review five policies. This review was done based on feedback received from the first board reading. The policies included in the review were: BP 1100 The San Jose-Evergreen Committee College District; BP 2015 Student Members; BP 2220 Committees of the Board; BP 2315 Closed Sessions and BP 2725 Board Member Compensation. The changes made by the Board Policy Ad Hoc Committee were submitted for a second Board review in red-lined format. Since there were no comments or changes requested, these five policies are now being submitted for approval. It's important to note that words which are underlined indicate language that was added since the last board approved policies and words that are in strike-through format language that was omitted since the last board approval.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Board Policies BP 1100, BP 2015, BP 2220 and BP 2725.
items.item_text: Approval of Board Policies BP 1100, BP 2015, BP 2220, BP 2315 and BP 2725
items.item_text_raw: 10. Approval of Board Policies BP 1100, BP 2015, BP 2220, BP 2315 and BP 2725

items.item_details:
As part of the accountability measures for the Measure G-2010 Bond Program, the management team for the program has put into place a formal process for managing, tracking and presenting to the Board of Trustees all revisions to the Measure G-2010 individual project names, scopes and budgets.  This process adheres to the accountability standards outlined by Proposition 39 and provides transparency in the evolution of the project list.
	 
In response to input received from the Board, additional criteria were added to the Bond List Revision process at the August 25th, 2015, Board of Trustees’ meeting.  These criteria identified an added layer of information and flagging to a Bond List Revision for those projects with substantive changes (a budget change to a single project in excess of $5 million dollars, the cancellation of a project from the bond list, or the creation of a new project).  Receiving further input from the Board, the management team will now separate Bond List Revisions containing “substantive changes” onto a separate, stand alone, Bond List Revision.  In the agenda text, the team will state whether or not the item contains substantive changes.
	 
Measure G-2010 Bond List Revision No. 22 contains substantive changes based on the criteria set forth above.  In this bond list revision request, Evergreen Valley College is cancelling Project 32106-Engineering and Applied Technology.  This project was dependent on matching state funding, unfortunately the state declined to fund EVC's Final Project Proposal (FPP) as currently planned.  EVC's updated Educational and Facilities Master Plans (adopted 12/15) has further rendered this project obsolete as it is currently scoped.  The remaining project budget is being transferred to various EVC projects to accommodate budget needs.  Project 32702-IT Infrastructure Improvements is receiving a budget increase exceeding 5 million dollars; $4,042,520.64 from cancelled project 32106-Engineering and Applied Technology and $1,041,270.27 and associated scope from Project 32314-Physical Security. Scope, status and name changes are also included on this revision.
	 
Please refer to the attached Bond List Revisions Approval Request report and the Summary of Current Changes report for details on each project revision included on the G-2010 Bond List Revision No. 22 dated April 12, 2016.
	 
These Bond List Revisions have been approved by the San Jose City College Vice President of Administrative Services, the Evergreen Valley College President and the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees review and approve the revisions to the Measure G-2010 bond list, as presented. This revision represents substantive changes resulting from the cancellation of one project and a budget increase exceeding 5 million dollars to another.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Bond List Revision No. 22-Substantive Changes
items.item_text_raw: 11. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: Bond List Revision No. 22-Substantive Changes

items.item_details:
Pursuant to the CCCT Board Governing Policies, the election of members of the CCCT board of the League will take place between March 10 and April 25. This year there are eight (8) seats up for re-election on the board.
		 
Each member community college district board of the League shall have one vote for each of the eight seats on the CCCT board. Only one vote may be cast for any nominee or write-in candidate. The eight candidates who receive the most votes will serve a three-year term.
		 
The fifteen trustees who have been nominated for election to the board are listed on the attached document sheet in the Secretary of State's random drawing order of February 12, 2016. An official ballot for the election is also attached, which will record the eight candidates chosen by the Board of Trustees at the meeting.  The ballot will then be signed by the Board President and Board Secretary and mailed to the CCCT Elections Committee in time to meet the April 25, 2016, deadline.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees choose eight of fifteen candidates nominated to serve on the California Community College Trustees Board.
items.item_text: CCCT Board Election 2016
items.item_text_raw: 12. CCCT Board Election 2016

items.item_details:
Per its adopted governing principles, the Board of Trustees will evaluate its performance at the end of each meeting.
	 
The Board will consider two items in discussing its evaluation:
	 
1.To ascertain the effectiveness of the meeting in attaining the advancement of the Board's Global Ends Policy.
	 
2.To ascertain the degree to which Trustees adhered to the Board adopted Governance Principle: Trustees Code of Conduct.
